now observed that he was pressing his hands

There was a lengthy pause. Sidney felt

ton, he would be acting decidedly in opposi-

How, then, could he serve one who appeared

dering boyhood-was enough to shorten his
guardian's life.
So, one day, in his youthful simplicity,
he had ventured to put the quest'on to Mr
Pilkington: " Is my little sweet heart, sir
a legal secret;?' For the thought that his
guardian might die, and he might never
learn what had become of tha child, was
the subject which troubled him most. But
he had no sooner made this inquiry han he
wished he had held his peace; for the follow-
ing day Mr Pilkington sent him back to
school, though the holidays were only half
over. He never again ha the courage to
question his guardian.
This old dread of Mr Pilkington-though
so many years had gone by -recurs to Sidney
when he goes that evening to join him in
the library; for he is but a boy compared to
this aged lawyer, and the fear of offending
him is still within him.
And yet, if he had yearned in his boy hood
to know something about that "little sweet.
heart he is yearning even more now to solve
the mystery of her disappearance.
Mr. Pilkington is warming his wrinkled
hand over the library fire; he looks at the
young man under his thick eyebrows. Can
Mr. Pilkington have observed-for they had
met at dinner an hour or two after Sidney's
visit to Took's Court-that Sidney is re-
volving some problem in his own mind?
Something in the old lawyer's manner as he
bends and warms his hand suggests an un-
usual sternness. "Sidney," says he, and
he voice is stern too-"sit down and listen
to me. -At least," he adds as the young
man takes a chair beside the hearth-'aisten,
Classed and men and and
guardian's words are like a direct challenge;
and yet he remains silent. The old dread
cannot in a moment be overcome.
His silence does not dispel Mr Pilkington's
displeasure; it seems to add sensibly to his
irritation. "Be careful, Sidney"-the old
lawyer admonishes him, raising his forefinger
impressively. "A secret character-a man
who does not confide in his friend-deserves
no compassion! I have some acquaintance
with such natures; and when you come to
know all our clients' secrets-and you soon
will now-you may learn that troubles arise
out of this very fault-secrecy. Profit by
experience-my experience. That is my ad-
vice to you."
Sidney, now essays to reply. Mr Pilking-
ton stops : Another time ; I am in no mood
to listen now.
Sidney more perplexed than ever at his old guardian's attitude, turns away; and the lawyer, still warming his hand over the fire,
looks after him with keenness as he goes

A Trillion Kisses.
The case of the Plymouth man who had
his love-letters produced and read in court,
should teach other lovers moderation in the

making of osculatory contracts, says London
Tit Bits. In a single postscript the Ply-
of his choice no fewer than 1,000,000,000,000
kisses, and as such contracts are not infre-
quently made in love-letters, it may be well

to give a thought to the magnitude of the undertaking.
Whoever will take the trouble to figure it
out will find that even if this amorous man
ahould give the lady 15,000 kisses a minute (and we affirm that no person could hope to do more than that), and even if he could keep up this rate of osculation twenty-four
hours a day, never pausing to sleep, eat, or
take breath, working 365 days every year,
it would take him more than 100 years to
complete the contract, and by that time, it
would be painful to reflect, the ardour of
his love may have cooled.
Even at the end of 100 years, counting
15,000 kisses a minute, there would remain
an undelivered balance of 200,000,000,000, a
number which in itself might appal the
most industrious. We therefore feel con-
strained to advise writers of love letters not
to undertake contracts of such magnitude.

Any one who walks through the woods
at this season will note the deep velvety
carpet of fallen leaves which covers the
ground. Few realize how much protection
this affords against frost. So long as land
is sheltered enough to prevent winds from
blowing away the leaves it is not apt to
freeze very deeply. The leaves act as a
mulch in the summer time, and this encour-
ages a growth of roots near the surface.
When the woods become thinned out so that
winds sweep them bare, the soil often
freezes down so as to kill the trees. No
matter how hardy a tree may be, it cannot
live when the soil freezes down to the depth
of the roots.

A gentleman who has recently returned
from Lisbon relates the following strange
coincidences in connection with the death
of the late King of Portugal. It appears
that when the Cathedral bell at Braganza,
the ancient residence of the Portuguese
Royal family, was tolling for the death of
Queen Marie 11., mother of the late King
Luiz 1, in 1853, it cracked, In 1861 when
the castle ensign was hoisted half-mast high
at Bragarz 1, on the occasion of the death of
King Padro V., brother of the late King,
it was torn to pieces immediately by the
storm. At the death of King Luiz 1. last
month the Cathedral bell again cracked
and the castle ensign was again tern to
shreds by the wind.

A new thing under the sun is proposed by
Captain J. P. Walker, a retired officer of
the army of the United States. This latest
Utopia is nothing less than a scheme by
which the ocean shall be robbed of its terrors.
Capt. Walker proposes to build a number of
light-houses, houses of refuge, and hotels
and plant themein the midst of the sea,
anchoring them at intervals between
New York and Queenstown. "From this

beginning he proposes to go on un-
til all oceans and seas shall be
detted with these structures, all connected
with each other and with the continents
and islands of the earth by telergraphic cable,
and supplied with vessels of various kinds,
which, with their crews, will constitute a
deep-sea messenger, telegraphic, and life-
savi ug service. 'While it would, perhaps, be
going too far to declare that the realization
of such a scheme is impossible, still there are
difficulties involved which render it quite
impracticable and improbable. Chief among
these is the financial question. Though
syndicates abound and millions of money
are represented as being paid for this and
the other industry, it is doubtful whether
our modern Cræsuses could be induced to
undertake any project which is so purely an experiment. It is not so sure a thing as buy-
ing up breweries, distilleries and such like.
Therefore until this question of cash is satis-
factorily settled it will be just as well for
those who seek summer resorts not to pre-
maturely felicitate themselves upon the
comforts and pleasures in store for them.

LASHED INTO WEALTH.
Mago's One Hundred Lushes Started His
Five Million Dolla's.
John James Mago, a middle aged, well
dressed man, has been in San Francisco, says
the "Examiner" of that city, for a few days
waiting for the Mexican steam or to sail. H
looks prosaic, but his career is as romantic
as that of Monte Cristo. Mago is now o
Guatemalan millionaire, who lives nine
months of the year at Paris. Fifteen years
ago he was a poor Eaglish collector of insects
in Guatemala, and also acted as British Vice
Consul at San Jose. One day Commandant
Gonzales ordered Mago to appear before
him. Mago sent word he would come in a
short time. This incensed the commandant,
who was ugly with drink, and he sent a file
of soldiers after Mago, and when the bug
collector appeared ordered seventy five lash-
es laid on his bare back. This was done
thoroughly, and when finished Gozzales
shouted:
"Give him twenty five more for lack."
When Mago recovered, which was only
after careful nursing, as his back was badly
cut up, he made formal complaint to the
British Government, The result was Gaute-
mala was ordered to punish Gonzales, and to
pay Mago $500 for every lash he received.
In default of this English cruisers would shell
San Jose and other coast cities. Guatemala
readily punished Gonz sles, but tried hard to
evade paying $50,000 to Mago. The Brit-
ish, however, were inexorable, and the poor
bug collector was made a rich man in one
day. As he had more coin than any one in
the country then President Barries entered
into partnership with him.
Mago became one of the largest coffee
planters and also secured the exclusive fran-
chise for building docks along the ports.
No one can land on or leave one of these
docks without paying $2 toll to Mago,
while he also levies a tax on all freight.
He also owns valuable mines and tracts of
timber. His fortune is estimated at $5,000,-
000, all due to 100 lashes on his back.
Mastering A Book.
The book which makes a man think most is
the book which strikes the deepest root in
his memory and understanding. One of the
educational maxims of the Jesuits is Vexatio
dat intettectum [Hard labor gives discern-
ment]. The maxim indicates that in the
judgment of these educators it is not working
at the easy but at the difficult mental task
that gives intellectual perception.
Men walk through a mountainous country
not only for the pleasure to be derived from
the scenery, but for the sake of the physical
vigor which comes from climbing bills. The
man who masters a book which keeps his
mind on the stretch is, like the mountain-
climber, braced up by the effort. He lays
down the book refreshed, invigorated, and
trained to master a more diment book.
One day while skating, an English boy dis
placed his knee-cap. He was taken home,
and the surgeon ordered him to lie for three
months on his mother's sofa.
He suffered severely from the pain, and
his wise grandfather handed him" a book to
puzzle over," that his attention might be
taken from the injured knee.
It was a work on trigonometry, of which
Henry Woodrow, the boy of sixteen, knew
nothing. At the end of three months, when
the boy was allowed to leave the sofa, he
had mastered the book, without any assist-
ance from any one, and in spite of the severe
pain in his knee.
Several years after the boy went to Cam-
bridge, where he did so well in mathematics
as to gain the rank of Fourteenth Wrangler.
He went out to India, and, as Director of
Public Instruction in one of the provinces,
did such good work that he was called "the
Nestor of Education in Bengal," and when
he died the natives raised three thousand
five hundred dollars to place his bust in
Caius College, Cambridge, and in the Uni-
versity of Calcutta.
The Bengal educator used to say that his
success at Cambridge and India was due to
his mastering the book his grandfather gaze
him "to puzzle over," when laid up with a
displaced knee-cap

One of the most extraordinary effects pro-
duced by absolute silence is recorded in the
reports of a Convention in which the fore-
most men in Virginia took part. John
Randolph had a measure to carry in which
he looked for the opposition of Alexander
Campbell, afterward founder of a large sect.
a man then noted for his scholarship and
power in debate.
Randolph had never seen the Scotch logi-
cian, but he had heard enough of him to
make him and his partisans uneasy. When,
therefore, the gaunt stranger first rose to
speak in the Convention, Randolph looked
at him with such an air of alarm as to at-
tract the whole attention of the Convention,
and as he glanced around seemed to be ask-
ing for sympathy in his coming defeat. He
then composed himself to listen in rapt at-
tention.
Campbell, aware of this by-play, hesitated
and lost the thread of his argument. Ran-
dolph's face by turns as he listened expressed
weariness, indifference, and finally unspeak-
able contempt. He leaned back and yawned.
Campbell sat down hastily. He had lost

A Fountain of Life.
On the fountain in King's Square, St.
John., is chiselled the quaint spiritual
truism which Jesus spake to a weary sin-
ner, in the shadow of Jacob's well, at
Sychar :- "Whosoever drinketh of this
water shall thirst again, but whoseever
drinketh of the water that I shall give him,
shall never thirst."
Beautiful message of love,
Would I with garlands enwreath !
Fountain of life, from above !
Fountain of life, from beneath !
What blessings your crystalline pureness
impart !
sing of the virginal life in thy heart.
This one : - the water of earth, -
Fraught with refreshing delight-
Pare and pellucid at birth-
Piessing to palate and sight,-
But though for immortal ones sent from
beneath,
'Tis leavened by sin with the virus of death.
That one, - (hush wearisome strife)
-Herald its praise abroad !
That, -is the Water of Life,
Fresh from the Fountains of God,
whose'-athirst-shall unto it
nigh.
And drink of its sweetness, he never shall
die.
Beautiful symbol of truth !
Thee, and thy lesson I laud,-
One, the Elixir of youth,
One, is the Spirit of God :
By this, shall the human a blessing obtain,
By that shall the Soul an Eternity gain.
Speak to the mortals who pass;
Ask them thy pureness to prove :
Many-unheeding alas !-
See not thy message of love,-
And seeing, they grasp not the truth it would
teach.
Or measure the meaning, more subtle than
speech.

Life's Review.
BY JOHN IMBIE, TORONTO.
The Old Year is dving,
His moments are flying,
On the "Ledger' of life may be seen:
Opportunities lant
To be faithfully spent,-
Whether "profit or loss" hath it been ?
Doth the Old Year's decay
Leave us wiser to-day
Than he found us just twelve months ago?
Have we done what we might?
Have we clung to the right?
Doth the "Ledger' a "credit-note" show ?
Have we cause for regret
At "the losses" we've met
Through sin, pride, or procrastination?
Let us humbly arise,
And resolve to be wise,
The New Year may bring consolation!
To thine own heart be true,
For 'ois wise to review,
And a "balance-sheet" strike without fear;
In life's sunshine or shower
Let each bright golden hour
Be well spent as if Death might be near !
When our Lord shall appear,
And our names we shall hear
Sounded forth from God's great Book above,
May the record then show
That "the debt" which we owe
Hath "been met" by His infinite love !

"How does the meaning strike you?" said
Millet, who had previously declared that he
intended by this picture to express the truest

worship. The painter's own faith was as simple as that of a child and firm as that of a wise wan.

"It means to me," said his friend, "that there is no use in prayer. There stand the

worehipping peasants on their dull fields
beneath a dumb black sky. Where is their
answer?"
Millet smiled, and with a few strokes of
his brush brought in a ray of sunlight from
the horizon. The whole gray sky lifted and
arched itself; the landscape from that one
beam was filled with hope and promise.
The commonest house decorator, follow-
ing the same rule, will tell you to light the
inside edges of your roof if you wish the
whole dwelling to appear lofty and cheerful
to its inmates.
Cannot our shrewd young readers gather
some hint from this for their daily occupa-
tions?
If the every-day routine of your life is
low-hurg, dull and gray, like Miller's fields,
let in some cheerful beam of light upon it.
Any monotonous occupation or round of
duties, however good or useful, wears on the
brain and nerves, and produces irritability
and ill humor. There are mornings on which
every member of a family appears at break.
fast under a cloud, the result, perhaps, of
overwork, dyspapsia, or some secret trouble.
How is the beam of light to be let in, and
the whole horizon of the day lifted?
If there is an artist in human nature in the
household with good will ar ... ot, he or she
will contrive some little gayety for the even-
ing, or an hour's stroll into the country, or
will bring home a good novel. Any amuse-
ment will answer which changes the current
of thought and recreates the wasted powers.
If your ordinary occupation brings you in-
to contact with masses of people, treat your-
self to a balmy interval of solitude; or, if, on
the contrary, you are too much alone, go into
a crowd. There is a magnetism, a stimulant,
which reaches us from human beings, more
powerful than any tonic.
Tuese are small rays or night, yes is is
surprising how quickly they lift our horizon
and widen our day.
At best, however, they are but homely,
practical methods which serve only a tran-
sient purpose. Every one of our readers
whose life is hopelessly dull and dead, surely
knows how to open it to the one true Light.
He Has Magnetic Fingers.
The scientists connected with the Johns
Hopkins University are engaged in investig-
ating the peculiar powers possessed by the
fingers of Louis Hamburger, the 21-year-old
son of Philip Hamburger, a well-known mer-
chant of New York. When the hands of the
young man are thoroughly dried and touched
to any polished object they hold it like a
magnet. He can thus raise up a quantity of
pins which will dangle from them, his index
fingers possessing the quality more than any
others. He also raises up a glass tuoe
freighted with a six pound weight. Profes-
sor William Simon has him in charge, and
proposes to give some scientific experiments
befere the Johns Hopkins Scientin Associ-
ation.
HOUSEHOLD.
Baby.
Before the cheerful fire to-night,
My wife and I are sitting.
We softly talk of days gone by,
And on our hearts, such memories lie
Of baby.
ar treasure was a boy, of course,
And such a sturdy youngster,
With hair of gold; and eyes of blue,
And six white teeth, so straight and true
Had baby.
His chubby hands, all dimpled, too.
And fingers, always itching,

And other tricks, to our surprise,
Did baby.
He made my wife a slave, all day,
Keeping him out of mischief.
He'd pick up pins and dirt, you see,
And put them in his mouth, would he,
Would baby.
And then, at night, when I came home,
He'd crow and smile, to see me.
He'd pick my pockets, do his best,
To grab my pipe (the little pest !)
That baby.
At hed-time, too, he'd ver us sore,
With all his restless antics.
And when we thought he was asleep,
Around the door, who then would peep,

And so to-night, we sit and think,
Ol baby's ways and doings,
And of those hands and voice, now still,
And through our hearts such memories
thrill.
Oh ! baby.
But, hark! From out the stillness comes,
A voice to soft and cooing,
That rascal, there, has just awoke,
And smiling too, a master stroke,
Our baby.
Washing in Winter.
I feel sure that among our many readers
some women are to be found who do, along
with sewing, cooking, sweeping, etc., the
washing for their tamilies. While it is
hard enough to do the washing any time in
the year, it becomes infinitely worse during
the winter months. The risk to be taken
then is incalculable.
The winter washings have been the

finding an early grave. Call it a dispensa-
tion of Previdence if you will, I call it a
result of hot steam from the tubs, combined
with carelessness. Rather strong language,
I know, but if you had seen, as I have,
seemingly sensible women go from the
steam-heated wash room to the clothes-line
in one hard, and tweed in the lace of a Folth.
ern or southern wind, proceed to hang up
the weekly washing without having taken
other precaution that to pin a shawl or
some other light wrap over their heads, you
would certainly agree with me that stronger
things might be soid. If a mother does not
care enough for herself to try to preserve
her health, she should at least do so for her
children's sake.
But the washing must be done. Certainly,
the washing must be done in winter as well
as summer ; but why not exercise a little pru-
dence? In the first place, the wash-room,
usually the kitchen, ought not to become so
heated by steam; the outside door should be
left open, slightly, to admit cold air, or
opened wide when the clothes are being
taken from the boiler. But the laundress
must not stand in the draught. Then when
the clothes are ready for the line, I would
urge you to let the "gude mon" hang them
out; true he may not hang them as scienti-
fically as you would, but you should be satis.
fied. His hands are not so susceptible to
cold as yours are. Indeed, I think it will
hurt no man to help his wife wash when
her one pair of hands must do so much.
It will be better, much better for you to
dry your clothes in the bouse. An attic to
dry clothes in is a luxury possessed by
few. Now, if you do not have your clothes dried in the house, and if there is no one to assist you, then do take some
care of yourself. Pall down your sleeves.
put a cloak on—a shawl will not do, for when you raise your arms it blows back, allowing the cold to strike you over the chest and langs. Put overshoes on, wrap
something warm about your head, and
wear mittens of cotton flannel or white
yarn, if you can use them, and tie a silk
handkerchief, or something equally close
over your mouth. I make this emphatic
for the reason that it is a precaution rarely
taken, and yet it is a most necessary one.
When one is warm, respiration is more
rapid, and it seems as though air could not
be taken in the lungs fast enough through
the nestrils; the result is that breashing is done through the mouth, and the air
as it were. The cold air striking the heated
lungs will certainly bring on some de-
rangement, and having the mouth tied up, thus compelling the nestrils to do their
own work, cannot, you see, be otherwise
than advantageous. We cannot afford to
run any risks where health is concerned.
Another thing I would urge is the wearing
of woolen dresses during the winter. So
many women wear calico and singham dress-
es, which are sure to find their way to the
wash every week, making additional work.
A flannel or cashmere dress, after having
been worn for best until it begins to look
shabby, can often be made to do service as
an every-day dress for one winter, any way,
sometimes for two winters, and need not be
in the wash, either, if one is careful. Many
women who do their own work buy half wool
dresses for every day. They of course line
them all through. Mach of the so-called
"cheap dress goods" will give as much wear
as the more expensive goods. Of course it
is closely woven goods that wear best.
One ought to study how to save washing
in winter. A pair of sleeves made to draw
over the dress sleeves, a rubber run in at the
Some Tested Recipes.
HAM SALAD, -One pound of boiled ham,
chopped fine; one-half dozen of small
pickles, chopped fine; add a little chopped
celery and serve with salad dressing.
CAPER BUTTER.-Rub a tablespoonful of
capers, finely chopped, through a sieve,
with a wooden spoon; add one-fourth
saltspoonful of pepper and one ounce of
cold butter, one saltspoonful of salt. Put a
layer of this under the fish to be served.

POTATO CAKES .- Take cold mashed pota-
toes left over from a previous meal and
form them into little oakes, using a little
flour to form them, but not mixing it into
the potate; arrange en a pie plate, glaze
with beaten egg and bake a delicate brown.
PRINCESS PUDDING, -- Butter well a pud-
ding basin, or plain mould, flour it well,
and etick, in rotation over the inside,
raisins, shoed candled peel, or dried fruit;
fill the basin with layers of bread and but-
ter, and between each layer, sugar, blanched
and sliced almonds, and cut candied peel,
with a grating of lemon peel over each
layer; pour ever the whole sufficient custard
to fill the mould-made with four beaten
eggs to a pint of milk-cover the basin
closely, and boil or steam from half to three-
quarters of an hour.
OYSTER PIE.-Line a buttered baking
dish with pastry and place in it a layer of
fine large oysters. Rub two tablespoonfuls
of butter smooth with as much flour and
place small bits of it here and there on the
oysters. Sprinkle with pepper and salt.
Follow this with another layer of oysters,
dotted with butter and seasoned as befere.
Continue this process until the dish is full.
Poor in enough oyster liquor to fill the dish
within an inch of the top and cover all with a rich pastry. Bake until a delicate brown,
rub over with a little butter or white of egg
and serve hot.
ORANGE Snow, -This is made the same
as snow pudding, except that the thin yellow
part of an erange rind is boiled five minutes
in the water that is to be turned over the
had relating and the inice of four large
sour oranges takes the place of the lemon
jaice, the quantity of water being diminish-
ed to allow for the difference in the amount
of juice used. The gelatine is beaten and the pudding is served with custard sauce or
whipped cream. Candied cherries or bias
of fruit or wine jelly dropped here and there
upon the snow of the pudding add much to
its appearance and also to its flavor.
Foultry and Meats.
BOILED TURKEY WITH CELERY STUFFIG.
-Chop half a head of celery very fine. Mix
with it one quart of bread crumbs, pepper
and salt to taste, two heaping tablespoonfuls
of butter, and two eggs. Stuff the turkey
with this, sew up and truss. Wring a large
equare of white cotton cloth out of cold
water, and dredge it thickly with flour.
Sew the turkey in this, and put into a pot of boiling water. Let it boil rapidely for
fifteen minutes; skim carefully, then set
back where it will simmer. Allow 3 hours
for a turkey weighing 9 pounds, and 12 min-
utes for every additional pound. Serve with
celery sauce. Cut the tender parts of a
head of celery very fine. Pour on just
water enough to cover it; cover the sauce-
pan and set where it will simmer one hour.
Mix together two tablespoonfuls of flour and
four of butter, and when the celery is tender
add this to it, with one pint of milk, and
salt and pepper to taste, and give the sauce
one boil before serving. It preferred, a
boiled turkey may be dressed with oyster
stuffing and served with oyster sauce. Sub-
stitute half a pint of chopped systers for the
colery in the above stuffing, and to make the
oyster sauce add half a pint of chopped
sauce, allowing the sauce merely to come to
the boiling point after such addition.
ROAST GOOSE. - Stuff the goose with the
following potato dressing: Six potatoes
boiled, pared and mashed fine and light;
one tablespoonful of salt, one teaspoonful of

pepper, one spoonful of sage, a tablespoon-
ful of very finely chopped onion, two table-
spoonfuls of butter. Truss. and dredge well
with salt, pepper and flour. A goose
weighing eight pounds will roast in a hot
oven in from one and a half to two hours.
To make the gravy: Wash the heart,
liver, gizzard and neck, and put on to boil
in three pints of water; boil down to one
pint. When tender, put the liver on a
plate, and mush fine, then return to the
water in which it was boiled, Mix two
tablespoonfuls of flour with half a cupful
of cold water; stir into the gravy, season
well with salt and pepper, and set back
where it will simmer for twenty minutes.
When the goose is done, take it up, and
tipping the dripping pan to one side to bring
all the gravy together, skim off every par-
ticie of lat. Place the pan on the top of the
stove and turn into it one cupful of water.
Lat this beil up, in the meantime scraping
everything from the sides and bottom of the
pan. Turn this into the made gravy in
the saucepan, boil up once, and serve in the
gravy tureen. With roast goose serve apple
sauce made as follows: Pare, core, and cut
up half a dezen tart apples, and stew them
in just sufficient water to keep them from
burning. When soft remove from the fire,
and heat and mash them smooth with suffi-
cient sugar to sweeten, adding, if you like,
a small bit of butter. Serve cold.
ROAST DUCKS. - The directions given for
reasting and stuffing a goose may be used
for ducks, with the same method of making
the gravy. Instead of apple sauce, currant
or grape jelly may be served with them.
GLAZED HAM. - Wash a fine corned-not
smoked ham; soak all night in cold water,
and boil about eighteen minutes to the
pound. There should be plenty of water in
the pot, cold at first, and brought gradually
to a boil. Skim well from time to time. Let
it get cold in the water in which it was
boiled; take it out, remove the skin care-
fully, and press soft paper on the top of the
ham to take off the clinging drops of grease.
Brush all over with beaten egg. Work a
cup of rolled and sifted soda or oyster
crackers into a paste with warm milk, butter,
pepper, salt, and a beaten egg. Coat the
ham thickly with this, and set to brown in
a moderate oven. When again cold, pin or
paste frilled paper around the knuckle.
PRESSED TONGUE. - Put a salt tongue into
cold water, bring it to a boil and skim;
then allow it to simmer at the back of the
stove for five or six hours. When tender.
remove from the pot, skin and cut away the
unsightly nortion at the root Prose the tim
removed way I have seared and room . Troops and Alfa
round to the root, and in this form place it
in a small round tin or saucepan its own
wize in circumference. The tin should be
flat-bottomed and have straight sides.
Cover with a cloth, over that place a small
round of tin or a plate, and upon that a
weight of at least eight pounds. After
being under press for ten or twelve hours
the tongue will turn out of the mould in
compact form, and should be carved in
slices across the top.

"They tell me you work for a dollar a day;
How is it you clothe your six boys on such
pay f
"I know you will think it conceited and queer.
But I do it because I'm a good financier.
There's Pete, John, Jim and Joe, and William
and Ned.
A half dozen boys to be clothed up and fed.
And I buy for them all good, plain victuals to
But clothing-I only buy clothing for Pete.
When Pete's clothes are too small for him to
get on.
My wife makes 'em over and gives 'em to John.
When for John, who is ten, they have grown
out of date.
She just makes 'em over for Jim, who is eight.
When for Jim they've become too ragged to fix,
She just makes 'em over for Joe, who is six.
And when little Joseph can wear 'em no more,
She just makes em over for Bill, who is four.
And when for young Bill they no longer wil
do.
She just makes 'em over for Ned, who is two.
So you see if I get enough clothing for Pete,
The family is furnished with clothing com
plete.
"But when Ned has got through with the cloth-
ing, and when
He has thrown it aside-what do you do with
it then?"
"Why, once more we go round, the circle com
plete.

Fish stories are always in order. Here i

Forest and Stream: "It's not uncommon is opening fish to find various and divers sun
e dries within their maws. On Lake Superio
t | the great lake trout namaycush of the Ojib
d bewas, seem to always be ready and willing
to accept any of such things as are thrown
from the cook's gallery of the steamers and
a sailing vessels which plow its pellucid waters
. It is not uncommon to find a fork or spoon
beef bones, potatoes, broken wine glasses corn cobs, and even a bunch of keys are among the treasure trove from their

omnivorous collection bags. But now a carp
comes to the front as a container of the neat-
est outfit of anything yet seen on the unsalt.
ed sea. On Christmas morning Captain McCormick, an old salt and fish man, saw
two fine large German carp on sale in Duluth
Struck with its appearance, and thinking
to please his friend, the doctor, he purchased
one and sent it to him with the compliments
of the season. Of course the doctor was
pleased with the gift and ordered it tabled.
You can imagine the astonishment of all
when it was opened to find within a silk-lined
case containing a large meerschaum pipe and
cigar holder, all in good order, too. It was
a genuine carp, imported from Germany, of
the variety called papier mache. The doc-
tor has it yet carefully preserved, and the
smoker's apparatus, too, which he shows to
his friends with very great pleasure.

Cycling as a pastime seems to be growing
in popularity almost every day, and that,
too, amongst the middle-aged and staid
members of society. It has often been sug-
gested that cyclists could be of great service
in times of war if properly drilled and train-
ed as soldiers, and many of our regiments
actually have cycling divisions. In a recent
number of the Wheelman there is published
a report of a most interesting inter-
view which the editor of that paper has
had with Lord Wolseley on the sub-
ject. His lordship is of the opinion that
cyclists can be of immense service in case of
war, and can also be made much use of in

ception of the worth and purchasing power

One day the lady, to carry out some ca-

n |
arout noon the promised money came, not

business?" was the next question.

A Canadian Absconder Heard From.
St. CATHARINES, Ont., Feb. 25-Mr.
David Mills, a widely-known traveller of
this city, writes to a friend here a letter
bearing date 12th of January, from Buenos
Ayres, Argentine Republic, South America.
He says: " On the 9th inst. I was walking
on one of the principal streets in this city in
company with my wife, when I suddenly
came face to face with a Mr. Macrae. He
was walking alone and looked very crest-
fallen and unhappy. He is certainly not the
Macrae of old, his jaunty air and erect car-
riage having disappeared under the trying
circumstances of the last few months. He
wore a light tweed suit and blue eyeglasses
and appeared to recognize me, but neither
of us spoke. I did not afterwards see him.
He is not extraditable i
whose
population is about one-third composed of
refugees from justice." It will be remember-
ed that the A. M. Macrae mentioned in this
letter is the dashing "Matt" Macrae,
formerly secretary-treasurer of the St. Cath-
arines Security Loan and Savings Com-
pany; who absconded with some $30,000
of the company's money in September! last.
A Cheap Way to Warm Cold Feet.
More than twenty-five years ago, I was
sometimes troubled with cold feet. At one
time while I was stamping upon the ground
in the effort to warm my extremities, a com-
rade said to me, "If your feet are cold try
this." He raised his foot from the ground
and struck some light blows with his hand
upon the upper part of his leg, just above
the knee. I did the same, with both legs,
and instantaneously felt a flow of warm
blood coming downward, and the feet be-
came comfortably warm.
The Night Air Oure.
Dr. Felix L. Oswald has contributed an
article to the Medical Tribune on "The
Night Air Cure," in which he maintains that
night air from the outside is far more health-
ful than the vitiated, disease-laden night air
of ordinary human dwellings. In Germany
successful experiments have been tried in
summer of having patients with pulmonary
disorders sleep all night in the open air of
the pine woods. At any rate it is all we
have to breathe at night, and it had better
be fresh and pure as possible.
"Eye-openers and Night-caps."
A physician, who declares that both the
"eye-opener" and the "night-cap" are very injurious, says that the latter is the less evil
of the two. "When a man," he says, "gets
to drinking early in the morning as a regu-
lar custom, he is pretty far gone. A drink
refore breakfast is a pretty certain indica-
tion of a half-dozen before sundown. The
effect of a morning drink wears away very
shortly, leaving the drinker collapsed just
at a time when he is busiest at work, and it
is natural for him to drink again to brace
himself up. At night, however, while he
sleeps, nature repairs the damage, or part of
it, which he has done by soaking his stomach with alcohol. If a man must drink, he
ought to have sense enough to steer clear of
the "eye-opener." It is the last resort
among drinkers and is the hardest to tear
loose from."
Air the Bedroom.
Will there ever be an end of the need of
saying that the room which demands most
careful attention is the sleeping apartments.
Bedrooms should be light, sunny and spa-
cious, and there should be constant change of
air, a window, either in the bedroom itself
or in adjoining room being partly opened at
night. If a chimney passes through the
room, a chimney in use, an opening into the
chimney covered with one of the simple perforated covers that may be closed at
need, makes the next best ventilator to that
of the open fireplace of the old days. And
now that flannel and cashmere nightgowns
are so much used, it will perhaps be easier
to persuade people that all-day underwear,

Coughing and Sneezing.
Coughing can be stopped by pressing on
the nerves on the lips in the neighborhood
of the nose. Sneezing may be stopped by
the same mechanism. Pressing in the neigh-
borhood of the ear, right in front of the ear,
may stop coughing. It is so also of hic-
coughing, but much less so than for sneezing
or coughing. Pressing very hard on the top
of the mouth is also a means of stopping
coughing, and many say the will has im-
mense power. There are many other afflic-
tions associated with breathing which can
be stopped by the same mechanism that
stops the heart's action. In spasms of the
glottis, which is a terrible thing in children,
and also in whooping cough, it is possible
to afford relief by throwing cold water on
bling the soles of the feet the
reet, or by ticking the soies of the reet, the
which produces laughter, and at the same
time goes to the matter that is producing
the spasm, and arrests it almost at once. I
would not say that we can always prevent
coughing by our will; but in many instances
these things are possible, and if you remem-
ber that in bronchitis and pneumonia, or
any acute affection of the lungs, hacking or
coughing greatly increases the trouble at
times, you can easily see how important it is
for the patient to try to avoid coughing as
best he can.
Cold and its Victims.
As might have been foreseen, the influence
of mere exposure upon health and life has
been unusually noticeable during the rigor-
ous close of the past year. Several cases of
reported in the metro-
this kind have been reported in the metro
politan daily press, and we cannot doubt
that their number would be largely increas-
ed if the facts respecting this matter were
fully known. Discretion in matter of expos-
ure is not indeed possible to all; but it
might certainly be exercised by, or on be-
half of, many persons, especially at the ex-
tremes of life, much more commonly than it
is. The spectacle of an aged man or infant
out of doors in biting weather must in very
many cases lack the excuse of necessity. It
is, however, where poverty or illness brings
privation that the pinch is most felt. The
safeguards afforded by food, fire and warm
clothing are most difficult of attainment.
Yet the poor and their charitable helpers
may take heart from the fact that the main-
tenance of sufficient artificial warmth does
not call for elaborate measures or lavish ex-
pense. The hand of brotherly help will cer-
tainly be appealed to, but it need not squan-
der or exceed in providing such absolute
necessaries as fire, plain bedding and flannel
underclothes. Food of the simplest is alone
requisite, if it be sufficient in amount and
warm; while the absence of alcohol is an ex-
cellent guarantee for needful economy and
for more sustaining provision. Much of
this care is within reach of the frugal poor:
but the time is fully ripe for charitable or-
ganization in relief of their pressing necessi-
ties.

THE PLUM HOLLOW SEERESS.
Death of a Woman Who Had Achieved
Fame as a Fortune Teller.
OTTAWA, February-Wordhas been receiv
ed here of the death on Wednesday night of
Mrs. Barnes, the famous Plum Hollow for
tune teller. Mrs. Barnes, during her life,
achieved far more than a local reputation as
a secress, people coming hundreds of miles
to consult her, not only as to what fortune
had in store for them but also by those who
had met with losses or were about to enter
into important undertakings. Many came
from New York and other American cities,
some from west of the Mississippi. During
the fifty years that she was actively engaged
in fortune-telling she was consulted by an
enormous number of people, and made a
vast amount of money. She was about
ninety years of age. She lived in a little
log cabin in a district called Plum Hollow,
about seventeen miles northwest of
Brockville. She was a mild-mannered
pleasant-voiced and exceedingly intelligent
woman and presented none of the witch-
like and uncanny appearances usually con-
sidered an essential element in connection
with successful fortune-telling. Her funeral
took place to the Athens Cometery. She
claimed to have exercised her alleged occult
powers since she was seven years of age.
Her father held a commission in the Eng-
lish army under George IV and for her di-
vining power was christened the "Star of
Connaught." by King William IV, who
presented her with a gold medal. Hundreds
of people throughout the Ottawa Valley had
Too Familiar
One may not, according to the etiquette
of loyalty, speak too familiarly of kings
and queens. As a subject was once remind-
ed, who wished to give his sovereign a pair
of stockings, "The Queen of spain has no
legs." She must not be supposed to walk,
talk, or eat like ordinary mortals, and if
one cannot escape the inference that she
really is like the rest of humanity, surely
nothing need be said of it.
When Queen Victoria visited Salisbury
Cathedral, thirty years ago, there was, of
course, a flutter of curiosity and loyalty
throughout the town. Even the humblest
houses had hung out some sign of rejoicing,
and at the White Hart Inn where the
queen intended to lunch, the landlady was
fluttering about in her best silk, while the
servants were gay with white waistcoats and
flowers in their button-holes.
But that this show of devotion was not
merely skin-deep may be guessed from an
occurrence of the late afternoon, when the
queen had departed.
In the coffee-room of the inn were two
young men wno were complaining to the
waiter because they were not given eels for
dinner, although the dish was promised
them. The waiter apologized profusely, and
remarked, in the way of excuse:
"Her Majesty has been here to-day."
"Did Her Majesty eat the eels?" was
the too familiar query, and at this the
waiter's loyal soul revolted.
"It's no business of yours or mine, sir,
what Her Majesty eats," was his dignified
To Stop Runaway Horses.
A Chicago man has made an invention
which will stop the wildest runaway team.
He is a livery man. Beneath the driver's
box a two-volt dry battery is located. in
the top of which are inserted three copper
pegs that project from the ends of the lines.
Running inside the lines are copper wires
forming a circuit through the horses' noses
by small polished balls of aluminum which
press lightly against the inner sides of the
nostrils. The circuit is opened and closed
by means of two buttons, one of which can
be operated by the driver. Should he be
thrown from his seat before he can press the
button, another button located beneath the
seat inside the carriage can be operated by
the occupant.
In addition to his device for stopping
runaway teams, the inventor has made an
electrical stimulator for starting lazy or
balky horses and giving them " style."
This is operated through the lines also, the
current being applied to the horses' sides by
copper plates in the back band.
Pa's Opinion of Them.
Neighbor's Wife (to little Johnnie, whose
mother has been dead nearly a year)-" My
poor boy, I shouldn't wonder if you would
have the widow Sparks for a stepmother
before long.
Little Johnnie (confidently)-" No dan-
ger of that. Pa wouldn't marry any one in
the neighborhood. He says their isn't a wo-
man in the village, married or single, who
knows when to hold her tongue."
Wash currants by dredging them with
flour, then rub them well with the hands to
remove the grit, pour water through until it
will run clear. Then let them lie on a clean
napkin until dry; never dry currants in the
oven.

THE MODERN PULPIT
MOMENTUM IN THE CHRISTIAN LIFE
BY REV. JOHN L. SCUDDEM.
(Congregationalist.)
"Go in this thy might."-Judges vi. 14.
History shows that great emergencies
never fail to bring forth a crop of great men
In all the notable movements of the past, the
international wars and civil conflicts, the
social and political upheavals, the intel
lectual and religious revolutions, our atten
tion is fixed upon one or more prominent
individuals who are identified with these
movements, and whose name are insepar
able from them. The name Cromwell
anach in English
suggests that turbulent epoch in English
history when the people stood up manfully
for their rights against both King and Pope.
Luther is synonymous with the Protestant
Reformation; Garibaldi with the struggles
of Italy toward political unification and
independence. The name Bacon marks a
transition in philosophy from the deductive
method-one of the most remarkable
changes in history; and Copernicus, ar
equally interesting change in the realm of
astronomy. The word Alexander is the best
representative of the ancient spirit of con-
quest, and Wendell Phillips of the opposite
modern spirit of personal freedom. And so
on throughout the list. Each occasion had
its conspicuous man or set of men, who stand
out in bold relief because they were men of
power-natural-born leaders of their fellow-
men.
There never was and never will be a time
without its great men. If the times are
dull, and there is no special demand for pub-
lic exercise of their powers, these men may
live and die unknown to fame; but they are
there for all that, and it takes only a little
agitation to bring them out of their obscur-
ity and place them in open view. When
Rome was in danger of destruction by the
Acqui and Volsci the people went instinct-
ively to Cincinnatus, who was plowing on
his little out-of-the-way farm beyond the
Tiber, and forced him to become their lead-
er. He threw aside his tunic, and putting
on his toga, led them to victory. During
our civil crisis a quarter of a century ago,
when slavery threatened to demolish the
Union, the people did not hesitate long
in determining who should command
ove courabt a long
the ship of State. They caught a long,
awkward, raw-boned man in Illinois,
and put him at the wheel. And well
did Abraham Lincoln honor and fulfil
the trust imposed upon him by an
appreciative people. 'Tis ever thus in the
history of human events. The really great
men outstrip their fellows and go to the
front, because they are men of might; be-
cause they have acquired a mental or moral
momentum which carries them through diffi-
culties before which the average man is forc-
ed to succumb. Our text furnishes us with
another such example.
The Midianites had surrounded Israel and
driven them from their homes into dens and
caves. The mountains were full of these
human vultures, who watched their prey
with wistful eyes and said within them-
selves, "Twill not be long before we shall
pounce upon you and eat you up. We are
only waiting for you to grow a little weak-
er." It was under these distressing circum-
stances that Gideon was sought by the
people of Israel and made dictator. He was
a man of valor and might, and for this rea-
son they thrust him forward and gave him
command. I need not cite further instances
of this sort; history is full of them. The
few that I have mentioned are illustrations
of a general law, which applies with equal
force to you and men in our particular
spheres of life. We may never be great, as
the world counts greatness-that is, we may
never become renowned and have our names
handed down to posterity for some brilliant
achievement; but it is true whatever of suc-
cess we do accomplish in any line of work
will be largely due to the principle I have
at of stored un now.
mentioned, namely, that of stored up pow
er of some sort, to the accumulation of ener-
gy, which can be used at any moment, like
money in the bank.
I wish to speak upon the principle of mo-
memtum in human life and character. We
appreciate the value of this principle in the
realm of mechanics; let us see if it has not
an equal value in the domain of spirit.
Take the following examples: Yonder is a
teamster coming down the hill with a load-
ed wagon. He notices that no sooner does
the road reach the bottom of the hill than it
leads up over another one, and in order to
relieve his patient animal of the superfluous
labor he makes use of this simple expedient:
When he is a few rods from the bottom of
the hill be loosens the reins, applies the
whip and acquires a galloping velocity
which takes him half way up the opposite
hill, and all this is done with scarcely
any expenditure of energy. About all
the horse has to do do is to keep on his feet;
momentum does the rest. It steals a march
on both gravity and friction. From this
country road let me carry you to a sawmill.
You see that circular saw flying round at
lightning speed, making hundreds of revolu-
tions in a minute. Watch it now as that
heavy piece of timber is brought in contact
with it. The second that saw strikes its fangs
into the wood it utters a shrill war whoop of
defiance and keeps up the battle cry until
its enemy is rent in twain and carried off to
make room for the next victim. The resis-
tance which that log of wood offered to those
revolving teeth is something enormous; some
thing which no one can appreciate until he
tries to make his way through that timber
with a common handsaw and vet. why is

THE LANGE OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF THE PARTY OF T
it that the circular saw spins through it
with ease and leaps out with a final twang
of triumph? How does it overcome this
tremendous resistance? You say it is steam
that drives it through. True enough, but
that is only a partial answer. Steam indeed
gives the power, but not the uniformity of
power which we observe. If you would
find the secret of this uniformity you
must go into the engine room and look at
that massive fly-wheel, weighingtons. When
this mighty balance is once set going, its
own great mass gives it a momentum that
brooks no opposition, and imparts a con-
stancy of movement to the entire system of
machinery. The buzz-saw, with this pon-
derous fly-wheel behind it, can accomplish
what it never could with steam alone.
One more example. Let me point out to
you what is known as a storage battery, an
ingenious modern invention for accumulating
electricity and holding it in readiness for
work. Such a battery is a prodigious power,
standing in the stable, as it were, with its
harness on, and capable of being brought
into action at a moment's notice. It is the
best illustration of reserve power that phy-
sical science affords. Now let us take these
hre e examples of accumulated force, and
see what they can teach us in the depart
ments of body, mind and heart.
It is every man's duty, I claim, to make
the most of himself, to be a man of
might in whatever sphere of influence God
has placed him by catching and condensing
the powers at his control and applying then
to some noble end. Looking at the average
human life, we notice a shameful waste of
power, men and women deliberately squan-
dering their energies, physical, intellectus
and spiritual, when by the exercise of a lit
- tle conscientious economy they might be a
hundred fold more powerful than they are and occupy higher stations than they at
present enjoy. I never could see any spe-
cial beauty in weakness. This quality may
ladmiration. It should be the ambition of
every one to be strong-a creature of accom-
plishment, obeying the commands of God to go forward in his might.
I remark in the first place that it is our
l duty to develop and husband that peculiar
bodily force known as vitality. These
bodies of ours are curious machines, in
which the vital energy may be gathered up

and kept in readiness for the strains of life.
They are veritable storage batteries, built
upon God's patent, and capable of being
charged with a subtler fluid than electricity,
and doing a much grander work.
There is a great difference in these bodily machines and the amount of vital force stowed away in them. Those who come into the world with vigorous constitutions may
thank their ancestors for charging their bat-
teries for them and giving them the very
Landon
best start in life. They are regular Leyder
jars stuffed with potential power and des-
tined to become forceful factors in the world.
Others, less fortunate in their ancestry, per-
haps, may thank Providence that their
early life was spent in the country, where,
during the first score of years, they develop-
ed enough vitality to carry them trium-
phantly through their three score years and
ten. These country boys have great reason
to be thankful. They possess in special degree
the power of endurance, the capacity for
bearing up under the numerous drafts upon
their energy. Their vitality is their momen-
ern break-neck speed when others less cop-
behind. And what a yearning there is in those of us who live in the city for
an occasional run into the country!
How we ache to get away from crowded
quarters and dusty streets; to leave behind
us the artificialities of civilization and come
into direct contact with the invigorating
forces of nature. What a stampede there
is for the rural districts during the sultry
summer months, where tired humanity may
recruit its flagging energies and replenish it-
self with sunshine and fresh air. This an-
nual exodus country-ward is a deep protest
against the physiological transgressions and
inconsistences of city life. The body cries
out for more sleep, more exercise more
simple fare, more green grass and blue sky.
All nature invites us to come and catch new
strength. And wee to the man who does
not respond to this urgent call. I believe it
to be a religious duty now and then to in-
terrup, our routine work, and fill up with
fresh life.
I believe in vacation not only for tired
ministers, but for everybody. A vacation is
like a running jump. When a man wants to
make a long and successful leap he goes back
a couple of rods to gather impetus. The
headway acquired during that brief run
sends him flying through the air. Now our
vacations do for us what these little runs do
for the jumper. They give us momentum
enough to keep us flying through the rest of
the year. That merchant is unwise who will
not give his clerks a couple of weeks vaca-
tion during the twelve months. Such recrea-
tion will not only put color into their
cadaverous cheeks; it will put cheerfulness
into their hearts and elasticity into their
entire composition. It will brighten them
up all over and make them tenfold better
workmen. Health is physical momentum;
we need to get all of it we possibly can.
The man replete with vitality can afford to
laugh at disease. Noxious germs can find
no abiding place in him. He sheds them as
easily as water-proof sheds the rain.
Now let us pass from the body to the
mind; from the reserve power of vitality to
that of discipline. Come back again to that
farmer's wagon. You recollect that in order
to travel easily over the up-grade in front of
him, he whipped up his horse and gathered
velocity and power on the down grade. In other words, he looked ahead, and made
ready to mount the hill before him. What
a lesson here for us who are travelling over
the great highways of life. Our courses here
are not over level roads which require little
expenditure of energy and offer no obstacles
to our progress. If I know anything of life
it mlantifully provided with un grades
T
I find it plentifully provided with ap-grade-,
and it behooves us sensible beings to prepare
for them. To make a success of life, to pass
with ease and comfort over the steeps before
us, we need a careful mental training as
well as bodily vitality. In youth, when
travelling is comparatively easy, we should
apply the whip to our intellectual faculties
and gain that momentum of discipline which
shall help us over hard places in days to
come. No one can over-estimate the value
of mental discipline as a preparative for the
graver duties of life. And it matters little
where we get this discipline, whether in the
school-house and the college, or the more
practical sphere of business. The special
value of an education lies not in the amount
of information picked up in the school room.
That is a matter of minor importance, as
every scholar will testify. In point of fact,
a large proportion of what we learned in
school has long since left us and passed
into oblivion. We could not retain our hold
upon the multiplicity of rules and dates
and facts. They slipped away from us be-
fore we were 20 years old, and, looking back,
we are compelled to say that the best thing
our schooling did for us was its training us
to think; to apply ourselves to difficult tasks
and overcome them; to depend upon our-
selves and work out our problems without
assistance. It gave exercise to our mental
faculties and toughened them, just as the
gymnasium develops the muscles of the ath-
lete and sends him away a man of might.
We may have left most of our information
in the school-house, but what of that? The
athlete does not carry away the Indian clubs
and the rowing machine upon his back, he
profits by their use, and comes out a man
capable of undertaking any task. Precisely
so, the real scholar, instead of cramming
himself with multifarious information, trains
himself rather to study, to master every
subject brought before him whether he re-
members it or not; he thus gains the indis-
pensible qualities of self-reliance, persever-
ance and thoroughness. The man who has
these, whether talented or not, is sure to
. | succeed in the end. His mind is like a
milldam, it is a reservoir of power, which
e can be applied to almost any use.
We see the same value of discipline in the
businessmen to-day started out as poor boys,
were at play. The discipline of poverty was
a hard one. The pay was small, the work
plenty and the hours long. Many a lad has chafed under such apparent hardship and
murmured against Providence for the un-
equal apportionment of her favors. But all
this time, remember, he was securing the best of training, he was forming those busi-
ness habits, without which in these days no
one can succeed. While rich men's sons are
growing up in idleness and ease, without in-
ial training or a knowledge of the value
CHAPTING PROPERTY OF TO WITHOUT TOURS OF THE LINE
of money, this young man, through his in-
dustry and economy, was developing into a
commercial giant. It was really his priva-
tions and enforced application that gave
him the impetus to outstrip his fellows in
the race for wealth. He steadily forged
ahead, while they, one by one, dropped be-
hind. There are blessed compensations in
this world, my friends; no bane but has a
corresponding blessing. The youngman start-
ing out at $5 a week thinks himself under-
paid, and perhaps he is from the standpoint of dollars and cents; but every day, if he is faithful, he is being paid off in increased
efficiency. He is gaining industrial momen-
tum, which by and by will pay him twenty
or thirty or a hundredfold more than his
actual labor's worth. During the first few
years of our active, independent life most
all of us were obliged to take a good share
of our pay in experience. But experience.
is a good school. It gives a grand discipline.
And now in closing I wish to say a few
words in reference to the third kind of
To be a man of real might, to make an un-
qualified success of life, one needs to add a
strong moral character to bodily vitality
and intellectual discipline. Nay; this last
is worth more than the other two combin-
ed. Now character is a growth. It is the result of a gradually accumulated spiritual power. Its force is nothing less
than the force of habit. When a man
once forms the habit of doing right,
and this habit becomes confirmed, he
acquires what we may call the mo-
mentum of righteousness-aspecies of mo-
mentum which is unaffected by temptation.
meneticin winds is critical control by company
Solicitations to evil have no power to turn
such a man out of his course or thwart his
progress. Sin is no more to him than the
log of wood to the buzz-saw. He cuts right
through it and flings the pieces to either side,
and the reason is that deep down in his soul
is the flywheel of moral principle. To such
a man, coming in contact with temptation is
a sort of amusement, not a dread encounter.
He goes through sin as a matter of course.
He has been traveling so long in this one
particular direction that he keeps on auto-
matically in the same good rut. I know people
who, during many years of holy living have
acquired such a godly momentum that it is
simply impossible now to throw them off
the right course. Like the planets of Heav-
en, they are true to their orbits. Nothing
can overcome the mighty inertia of
their holy habit, or cause them to swerve
in their faithful revolution around the sun of
righteousness. This is in fact the old doctrine
of the perseverance of saints.
Of what paramount importance is this
principle in the education of children! The
parent or preceptor who fails to apply it with
all his might is guilty before God for a gross
breach of trust and wasted opportunity. If
we would save our children when the evil
days come, as come they will, we must plant
these godly habits in them early in life and
cultivate them with utmost care. The roots
must grow stout and strong and take hold
of the rocks before the storm breaks. Your
tree cannot do much growing in the thunder-
ing gust; remember that. The growing and
strengthening must be done beforehand.
And what has been said of temptation is
licable to our discours coments and
also applicable to our discouragements and
trials. We need divine power to carry us
through these without wavering or doubt;
nay, more than that, we need a
store that has been accumulating for
years through faith. It is a dangerous
thing, we are told, for a vessel to lose
its headway in a heavy sea. It is liable to
get into the trough and be swamped.
Equally hazardous is it for a man to lose his
faith in God; and many is the poor fellow
who, having thus lost his propelling power,
has made shipwreck of his immortal soul. I
have noticed that when great afflictions
come upon them, irreligious men, are often-
times very weak. They seem to labor
heavily in the tempestuous waters and are
at their wits' end, whereas the godly soul
mounts the waves as lightly as a clipper
ship.
In the year 1885, when the Germanic, of
the White Star Line, was making her home-
ward journey from England to New York, she
encountered one of the most terrible gales
that ever swept across the Atlantic In the
course of this tempest Capt. Kennedy said
that a wave of mountainous proportions
lifted itself up against the vessel and threat-
ened to engulf it. It lay directly in the
track of the steamer and stood higher than
the top of her smoke-stacks. It was simply impossible for the vessel to override it, and
so with her terrific momentum of eighteen
miles an hour she plunged headlong into it
and was completely buried from stem to
stern. That was a moment of awful sus-
pense to every person upon that steamer. It
seemed as if their end had surely come. The
skylights were destroyed and the water
rushed in until the passengers stood
waist deep in the cabin. One
sailor was washed overboard, and the cap-
tain in the wheel-house was knocked insen-
sible. All the lifeboats were swept bodily
away and the iron railing was torn and
twisted up like twine. The vessel was lit-
erally stripped by the seething waters; but
being sharp and heavy, and possessing an
irresistible momentum, she actually tun-
neled her way through this mountain of
water and came out on the other side. She
trembled all over, as it conscious of her
peril, and staggered beneath her ponderous
load; but thanks to her tremendous head-
way she burrowed through what to most
vessels would have been a watery grave,
and shaking off her liquid burden proclaime 1
her victory over this mighty monster of the
deep Our trials, dear friends, are like
those billows of the sea. We are compelled
to meet them, whether we will or not, for
in the voyage of life, before we reach the
western haven of rest each one of us is
certain to have his share of trouble. All
afflictions are grievous to be borne, and now
and then one comes which makes the
soul shiver in every fibre of its being,
and threatens it with destruction,
Down goes the soul in the dark
waters of misery, and it is a question som
times whether it will rise again and shake o
its load of sorrow. As a matter of fact, som
people never do survive these terrible ex
periences; orce thus submerged, they giv
up in despair and sink out of sight. But th
true Christian, trusting in God and
"strengthened with might by his spirit is
the inner man," never loses his headway
even though troubles rise up mountain high
If he cannot go over them he has God-given
power to go through them and come ou
more than conqueror on the other side. Ou
trials may strip us dear friends, but they
cannot overwhelm us if the motive power o
faith in God is strong and real. Take thi
power to-day and make it your own. It wil
help you through the trials of this life, and
dive you an abundant entrance into the life
TELEGRAPHIC TICKS.
In Montreal there was a change of 48° in
the temperature in 24 hours, more than
the range for a whole year in Florida.
The mayor, aldermen, and city officials o
Minneapolis, Minn., to the number of 35
intend shortly paying Montreal a visit.
The Assistant Secretary of the United
States Department of State says there is no
of record any treaty having been agreed upon
between the United States and Newfound
land.
At its meeting on Monday night the To
ronto City Council by unanimous vote ap
pointed a special committee to enquire into
the leasibility of securing water by gravi
tation from Lake Simcoe.
The Hamburger Nachrichten expresses con
tempt for the threatened persecution of it
self and Prince Bismarck, and says it will
take full responsibility for everything the
Prince has written, his motives being patri-
otic and not ambitious or revengeful.
In the Montreal Superior Court the city
and Policeman Limoges were condemned to
pay Courcelles the sum of $500 and costs on
account of injuries inflicted upon him by the
policeman, who arrested him with unneces-
sary violence last September.
A Jewish rabbi and a physician, living
in Grodno, have been exiled for two years
for sending a petition to the Government
on behalf of a Jew boy, accused of larceny,
who had been branded on the forehead with
"thief" in three languages by a Russian
doctor.
Father Maissonneuve, a veteran mission
ary, who went to the North-West in 1848,
when he performed the greater portion of
the journey in a vehicle drawn by steers, is
at present on a visit to Montreal. He is 66
years of age, and quite deaf from the hard-
ships he suffered.
Saddler, who was arrested in White-
chapel on suspicion of having murdered
"Carotty Nell," was brought before the
Police Magistrate the other day. Evidence
was given that he was seen in the company
of the woman shortly before her death, and
the case was adjourned till the 24th inst.

The decision of judge Thayer of Missouri,
if sustained, will do much to rob the Alien
Labor law of its terrrors for those manufac
turers and others who desire to import work-
men from abroad. The case which the learn-
ed judge was called upon to decide was that
of a manufacturer in Missouri who wrote to
workmen in England, telling them he could
give them steady work, and sending them
tickets, which they used in coming from
England to this country. Judge Thayer
holds that the letters and the sending of the
tickets "do not constitute an express con-
tract." In the light of this interpretation
it will not be difficult to evade the law which
unless modified so as to accomplish the thing
intended, had a thousand times better be re
pealed. Otherwise its existence on the
statute books will only tend to break down

Chicago and the horld's Fair.
Chicago is perplexed. The World's Fair
which it was supposed could be carried
through for $10,000,000 is now estimated to
require at least $15,000,000, of which the
greater part will require to be paid out be-
fore any returns from the Exposition comes
in. Where to get the more than $5,000,000
over and above the amount subscribed by
private citizens and the amount derivable
from the city's bonds is a question that is
troubling the Executive Committee. Some
suggest bonding the gate receipts to the ex-
tent of $5,000,000, while others who oppose
this as seeming too much like mortgaging
a patriotic enterprise, affirm that the capi-
tal stock of the Exposition Company must
be increased to $10,000,000 without delay.
Should the gate receipts realize
phonin the gave receiped realize an onat to
expected there will still remain a difference
of nearly $5,000,000 between the expense of
providing the show and the gains derived
therefrom. Had the people of the garden
city foreseen what they now know, it is
questionable whether they would have fought |
so persistently for the honor and-the
labor.

Death From Fright.
An inquest was held in London on atur-
day, on the body of Ada Lousia Elflain,
aged 16, a factory hand employed at a rope
works. Emily Davis, a fellow worker, stated
that the deceased had only been employed
at the factory for about a fortnight. On
Thursday, about mid-day, the deceased and
witness were working side by side, when the
deceased suddenly put up her hand, and
witness knew that something was wrong.
On going to see she found that the pin of the
machine had broken. Deceased suddenly
fell on the floor, and witness being unable to
revive her, sent for a doctor, who on his ar-
rival, pronounced life extinct. By the Jury:
The pins did brake occasionally, but there
was no danger attached to their doing so.

Mr. McLean in his address states th
his reason for opposing Bryson is becau
he did not fulfil his promises respecti
the bonus. When Bryson asserted th
the county would not have to pay a ce
of it, he supposed that it was not o
women or children he was ad lressing, b
men who would put a common-sense i
terpretation on his words. He did n
expect to find an elector so ignorant as n
to know that neither he nor anyone el
could say with certainty what the decision
of the courts would be; but he believe
in his immost soul that the claim
the bond holder was unjust and therefo
unlawful. Weighty legal opinion co
firmed him in this view, then what he be
neved to be fact he asserted as fact. The
courts have rendered an adverse decision
but how is he responsible for that? What
wrong has anyone suffered beyond disag
pointment, and in that no one suffere
more than himself. The attempt, then
to lay the odium of the bonus on Bryson'
shoulders is only a mean election dodge-
he had nothing to do with it. It was Mr
. McLean's mission to saddle us with it
and he saddled us, entirely to his satis
faction, realizing $11,000 by the job, a
soon as the girths were tightened. . Nov
the electors should consider which of the
two men is more worthy of confidence
Hector McLean, who moved heaven and
earth to induce the county to grant the
bonus, in which he unfortunately suc
ceeded, and then put more than one
tenth in his pocket, which comes out of
the pockets of the electors; or John Bry
son, who never took any part in rivetting
it on us, made no money by it, but lost
money as well as time in trying to free us
of it.
Mr. McLean brings no other charge
against Mr. Bryson than that of the bon-
us; this speaks well for the latter; it
shows, too, that if Mr. McLesn has any-
thing to say against him it is on some
small and quite local matter that he is
unwilling to bring forward as he knows
it would not be acceptable to the majority
of the electors, though it might suit him-
self and a few wire pullers well enough.

runs may read, we believe that just now
the interests of the county are safer in
Bryson's hands than in those of his wor-
thy opponent. We rather mefer to trust
the man who is not ashamed to say that

has raised Canada from colonial obscurity

Empire, than the man who in his first ad-
dress comes out as an Independent, in his
second as Independent-Liberal-Conserva-
tive, and whom we may expect to hear

Monday, May 4th. - The House met at
at 3 p. m. on Friday, May 1st, with the
newly elected speaker in the chair. A
large number of petitions were presented,
after which his excellency's speech from
Throne was taken up for consideration.
Mr. Hazen, of St. John, N. B., was the
mover, and Mr. Carbould of British Col-
umbia, the seconder of the address. Both
gentlemen made able speeches, showing
the progressive policy of the Government,
in having acquired and opened up the
North West, thus adding to the prestige
which Canada enjoys in the world, and
that while willing to treat on fair terms
with our neighbor to the south of us, yet
would not go so far as to imperil our con-
nection with the motherland or forfeit
medelon when the middle control of the solder
our allegiance to the British Flag, under
whose protecting folds we have so long
lived and prospered. That the financial
affairs of the country are in a healthy
state, and that we were paying a lower
rate of interest than at any time since
confederation. Mr. Hazen said the people
of New Brunswick had declared against
